messages.content: RE: Press 35 & 36 Updates - Temperature Feedback PID Loop Test Runs: Steam Automation

My pleasure Joe.  Yes sir I understand that the process HMH has implemented doesn’t require precise readings, feedback, etc., so I definitely don’t want anyone to feel like I am questioning things or coming across as an auditor.  The only thing is that when we implement this automated control systems, we must program in as precise measurements as possible for a baseline that the controller can operate from.  But I am handling all of this already as I am manually entering the Fluke readings into the data logs via the HMI, and I only shoot specific areas on the platens that are ~1” in diameter that will give me the highest temp of the platen.  See attached for a graph I just generated from the testing I was doing last night.

 

So, if the operators are going to be taking measurements of the platens and documenting them to compare against the automation system, I would request that we make sure they know where the hottest area is on each platen, and to document the small lower reading from the IR gun instead of the larger one for the reasons I mentioned previously.  Using that smaller read out from the IR gun will give them the highest value within the ranges you mentioned below.  Also If an operator were to shoot this black spot below on the bottom platen of press 36, they would not receive an accurate reading of the highest temp as there is no section within that circle that reaches it.  There are areas in the black circles of several platens that can off by 10° or more from the hottest reading.

 



 

I would be happy to show the operators where the specific 1” diameter spots are on each platen that I am shooting.  I could also show someone in management if you all don’t want me to give them any directives.  Over time I have gotten to know many of the operators very well here and they are great guys….definitely don’t want to ruffle any feathers, etc., again these are just suggestions\recommendations.

 

I am not sure I understand your question highlighted below, we currently have two thermocouples installed on each platen that are secured with a custom block that I had manufactured, and the probes are in direct contact with the platens.  Please let me know if this is not what you were referring to.

 



 

Thank you,

Miguel 

 

Miguel​​​​ Grillo	
Automation Consultant	
office	
(713) 944‑2100	
cell	
(713) 446‑2879	

From: Incavo, Joseph <Joseph.Incavo@hmhw.com> 
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2024 12:55 PM
To: Miguel Grillo <miguel.grillo@awc-inc.com>
Cc: Walker, Chad <Chad.Walker@hmhw.com>; Baran, David <David.Baran@hmhw.com>; Guillen, Enrique <Enrique.Guillen@hmhw.com>; Farzana, Nusrat <Nusrat.Farzana@hmhw.com>; Deruyter, Marty <Marty.Deruyter@hmhw.com>; Estrella, Robert <Robert.Estrella@hmhw.com>; Morales, Rogelio <Rogelio.Morales@hmhw.com>; Waller, Davidt <Davidt.Waller@hmhw.com>; Wallace, David <David.Wallace@hmhw.com>
Subject: RE: Press 35 & 36 Updates - Temperature Feedback PID Loop Test Runs: Steam Automation

 

Many thanks Miguel.

 

This highlights the inherent problem with using emissive guns as our primary temperature measurement tool.  

HHP has done the best they can with standardizing on a painted spot, but the reality is the operator is still always presented with a spread of values. 

 

Question:  is there a thermocouple probe that can measure temp at the existing spot on the platen without presenting a safety issue ?

 

 

Regards,

Joseph Incavo, Ph.D.

Engineering Director

Elastomer Center of Excellence

Tel: 346-267-6913 

joseph.incavo@hmhw.com <mailto:joseph.incavo@hmhw.com>   |  https://hmhw.com <https://url.us.m.mimecastprotect.com/s/5O45CNkjQziZgnyyi4veBL?domain=hmhw.com/>  

SDS JFK
3300 North Sam Houston Pkwy East, Houston, TX 77032, USA



   

 

 

 

Internal

From: Miguel Grillo <miguel.grillo@awc-inc.com <mailto:miguel.grillo@awc-inc.com> > 
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2024 12:45 PM
To: Incavo, Joseph <Joseph.Incavo@hmhw.com <mailto:Joseph.Incavo@hmhw.com> >
Cc: Walker, Chad <Chad.Walker@hmhw.com <mailto:Chad.Walker@hmhw.com> >; Baran, David <David.Baran@hmhw.com <mailto:David.Baran@hmhw.com> >; Guillen, Enrique <Enrique.Guillen@hmhw.com <mailto:Enrique.Guillen@hmhw.com> >; Farzana, Nusrat <Nusrat.Farzana@hmhw.com <mailto:Nusrat.Farzana@hmhw.com> >; Deruyter, Marty <Marty.Deruyter@hmhw.com <mailto:Marty.Deruyter@hmhw.com> >; Estrella, Robert <Robert.Estrella@hmhw.com <mailto:Robert.Estrella@hmhw.com> >; Morales, Rogelio <Rogelio.Morales@hmhw.com <mailto:Rogelio.Morales@hmhw.com> >; Waller, Davidt <Davidt.Waller@hmhw.com <mailto:Davidt.Waller@hmhw.com> >; Wallace, David <David.Wallace@hmhw.com <mailto:David.Wallace@hmhw.com> >
Subject: RE: Press 35 & 36 Updates - Temperature Feedback PID Loop Test Runs: Steam Automation

 

	CAUTION:This email is originated outside of the HMH organization. Exercise caution when responding, opening attachments, and clicking links. 

Joe,

 

Please review my feedback below in blue and let me know if you have any further questions:

 

We understand you will be correcting each of the 4 thermocouples with an offset value to meet the spec value. For instance, gun value = 280, TC reads 287.5, offset is -7.5.  

Will the display show the corrected TC values so that a comparison of the spec value and the actual (corrected) value will be shown ? The point here is that when we walk up to a display we want to see Spec Value and Actual Value.

            

            Currently we are only displaying the temperature measurement from the thermocouple in contact with the platen.  I will add an additional output field right next to it that will display the “corrected” value with the offset calculated which theoretically would show the operator what value they should be reading when measuring with the Fluke 561 IR Thermometer.  That being said, I think it would be a good idea to have a general discussion about how the operators are using the 561 to determine the temperature, especially if they are going to be comparing with the automation system.  There are only a few specific areas on the platen that will provide the maximum current temperature which I feel we need to use as a baseline.  Furthermore, the operators need to make sure they are documenting the smaller value on the display from the IR gun instead of the larger value.  The smaller value holds the maximum reading during the ~7 second instance of the IR shoot.  Notice below how I am reading within the spray-painted spot for press 36 and the reading is 134, but during the time that I was taking the IR reading, I crossed a section that was 145.  Just wanted to bring this to everyone’s attention, the operators might already be doing this.  I am going to speak with a few of them now to get a better idea of which display value they are noting.

 



 

Will the display also show which step, time in that step, total time, time remaining ?

            

            Yes sir that is already programmed into the PLC\HMI

 

Does the coding provide any flagging of setpoints not met after some period of time ? 

            

            Yes sir we have implemented time-based thresholds that will alarm\alert and take action if feedback is out of a specific range from the setpoint for a specific period of time.  I can send that information later if you want and we can always adjust it if needed, I will add an “admin” section as well on the HMI where specific users can change those parameters if needed.

messages.content: RE: Press 35 & 36 Updates - Temperature Feedback PID Loop Test Runs: Steam Automation

Joe,

 

Please review my feedback below in blue and let me know if you have any further questions:

 

We understand you will be correcting each of the 4 thermocouples with an offset value to meet the spec value. For instance, gun value = 280, TC reads 287.5, offset is -7.5.  

Will the display show the corrected TC values so that a comparison of the spec value and the actual (corrected) value will be shown ? The point here is that when we walk up to a display we want to see Spec Value and Actual Value.

            

            Currently we are only displaying the temperature measurement from the thermocouple in contact with the platen.  I will add an additional output field right next to it that will display the “corrected” value with the offset calculated which theoretically would show the operator what value they should be reading when measuring with the Fluke 561 IR Thermometer.  That being said, I think it would be a good idea to have a general discussion about how the operators are using the 561 to determine the temperature, especially if they are going to be comparing with the automation system.  There are only a few specific areas on the platen that will provide the maximum current temperature which I feel we need to use as a baseline.  Furthermore, the operators need to make sure they are documenting the smaller value on the display from the IR gun instead of the larger value.  The smaller value holds the maximum reading during the ~7 second instance of the IR shoot.  Notice below how I am reading within the spray-painted spot for press 36 and the reading is 134, but during the time that I was taking the IR reading, I crossed a section that was 145.  Just wanted to bring this to everyone’s attention, the operators might already be doing this.  I am going to speak with a few of them now to get a better idea of which display value they are noting.

 



 

Will the display also show which step, time in that step, total time, time remaining ?

            

            Yes sir that is already programmed into the PLC\HMI

 

Does the coding provide any flagging of setpoints not met after some period of time ? 

            

            Yes sir we have implemented time-based thresholds that will alarm\alert and take action if feedback is out of a specific range from the setpoint for a specific period of time.  I can send that information later if you want and we can always adjust it if needed, I will add an “admin” section as well on the HMI where specific users can change those parameters if needed.

 

Thank you,

Miguel

 

 

Miguel​​​​ Grillo	
Automation Consultant	
office	
(713) 944‑2100	
cell	
(713) 446‑2879
